Because, as someone said,"The only problem is, after a while you start thinking "how come none of this ever happens to me?", and you start getting beautifully depressed, and then just plain depressed, and at the end you leave the theatre feeling utterly miserable."Now this is a feeling I had too(and a very strong one indeed!).

title: lovely, engrossing
content: There was a fellow whose home videos invariably annoyed me.  One day I realized why; each time a conversation began -- something beyond "Hi, mom!" and waving -- the tape would cut and the next scene would begin.One begins to wonder -- does this person even LIKE people?  Apparently the stuff of real life seems too dull for some, and they need Entertainment; the amperage on that entertainment has to keep going up and up, also, because we develop immunity toward all of our fixes.  Thus, we wind up with ARMAGEDDON, GODZILLA, et al, or soap opera hysterics; everything pushing the envelope just so we can feel a little (and recognize a movie's cues to us).I thought BEFORE SUNRISE was great not as a reaction against that, but because it's so obvious Linklater and his actors give a hoot about human beings.  Yes, some of the dialogue -- which is very, very sharply observed -- is silly and pretentious; these are kids who want to impress each other, like each other, and enjoy "deep thoughts."  It reminded me so much of college: that thrill of ideas, possibilities, yearnings.The movie looks beautiful and is terribly romantic.  Thank God Linklater is savvy enough to play out some conversations in long takes; a cumulative effect and rapport is built between Delpy and Hawke, their pinball game, and us.  They're both movie-star beautiful, but for a while, they're just regular folk.Kubrick and Hitchcock may be better directors than say, Linklater or Levinson, but their cold formalism does make one wonder what grudge they hold against people.  The Coens seem to be warming as well -- FARGO and THE BIG LEBOWSKI bespeak a new affection in their clever hearts.  But, for my money, give me a director who loves people -- a Sturges, a Lubitsch, and, yes, Linklater -- and their works will shine in a way that some geniuses' never do.

title: Mixed response by age
content: Erwin-Jones Thursday Family Film Night. Chosen by Jess. Mixed response to this one. Jess adored it, I found it dull and Sarah stated that she'd have loved if she'd watched it in her 20s (when it was made) but found it over long. ***

title: the most wonderful film
content: i almost didn't bother watching this film. while i like richard linklater, i certainly did not like "the newton boys", and i was sure that this was another studio produced clunker. but i gave it a shot for the heck of it. i am so glad i did. this is the most perfect movie i have ever seen. by far my favourite. it holds up even after about fifty viewings. it hits every single not exactly right. a few of my favourite scenes are the scene in the listening booth with the kath bloom song, the poet scene and his poem, and scene where they pretend to talk to their friends on the telephone. the ending is so wonderful and anti hollywood that i cannot believe they let rick get away with it. depending on your point of view, check out "waking life" to find out what happens to the couple after the movie. it could be real, or it could be a dream though, you'll never know... i wish more people knew about this flick!

title: Totally lack of taste after all that great love stories..
content: I watched this movies very soon on an advice of a friend who made me feel like I am missing a must see movie. It is really hard for me to understand why this movie is supposed to be one of the best love movies made ever. I kept watching through the end to find a reason behind overrated interest to the movie. Celine and Jesse..both are much more into pretending than falling in love,they keep talking about usual things throughout the movie and in the end make you experience what real boredom is. Only attractive point might be beautiful scenes from Vienna but this is even not good enough to give a reasonable rate to this movie.

title: wrong era
content: This movie is so good. The acting ,the story, the directing its all excellent.Its like a movie from the 40s was shoot in the 90s. There are no special effects and monsters. There are these two talented actors acting two people in love.I never before have seen a movie who talks about life as I see it.I think that both Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke did an excellent job because there were times when I forgot I was watching a movie.

title: Beautifully romantically & intellectually stimulating
content: "Before Sunrise" is perhaps my all time favorite movie.  It not only portrayed the random encounter of 2 complete strangers incredibly romantically, it also added a flair of "je ne sais quoi".  This is perhaps the best movie I have seen where intriguing conversations drive the movie. A must see.

title: "Before Sunrise" should be more popular
content: It's a nice story with beautiful pictures and great actors. A very realistic, simple and romantic love story. Two people meet each other begin to talk and decide to spend the day and night together in Vienna. This is how a real romance should begin. The American who has a flight from Vienna home the next day and the Frenchwoman walk trough Vienna and talk about all the world and his brother and fell in love, it's so simple and that makes it realistic. It's a slow movie but never boring. And Vienna was never shown in such a beautiful way and never look more amazing. It's not only because I'm from Austria and know Vienna, but I like "Before Sunrise" more than "Before Sunset", even this a nice sequel too.

title: Empty spiritedness
content: By now you may know that this is about two people falling in love around Vienna and otherwise cinematically plain. Beautiful young faces, beautiful old Europe, in principle very much a European film such as Woody Allen has fantasized about it, if not in actual spirit. He is cynical and boyish, she is a dreamer, excited, open to the flows of life. They listen to music, talk, walk, have their palms read, a really dreamy summer night of sharing and intimacy.We stick it out because at dawn it expires, and the lives of mundane responsibilities are resumed. It is a parting like death of sorts, like someone is going out of life. How will they handle it? Will they fiercely cling at what they shared? Will they accept the memory of it?There is however a second movie that came out 10 years later, where we get to find out whatever happened between these two, or didn't. So for all intents and purposes, whether originally designed so or merely improvised along the way, this is only one half of a full movie - very much like Wong Kar Wai's In the Mood for Love. The resolution is predictable, the heartbreak postponed for another sunrise. Oh, we get to know these two really well, whether we like it or not. They are full of opinions, dreams, rebellions, a lot of empty spiritedness like is common in youth discovering a larger world. We get to know them well enough to imagine some pain ahead of them, the bill for the good times enjoyed here.But unlike In the Mood for Love, this has none - perhaps one, the big ferris wheel at sunset - of the melancholy moods to wrap around us, that will allow us to permeate the silence behind words where love runs deeper, richer. It is not cinematically succulent in any ways that I am seeking out.Being from that slacker generation that gave us Tarantino and Kevin Smith, it's a film illustrating a screenplay. The effort is for quirky emotion and smartness. A romance and connection from words, instead of romance from the profoundness of rhythms and gestures. Forgettable work.

title: One of the best romances!
content: At first I expected a boring romance seen a hundred times before, but after watching the movie I am stunned of its greatness.The fact that this romance takes place in Vienna is superb. I was there 6 months ago and I fell in love with the city. In my opinion, one of the most beautiful cities of the world!I recognized some places, although the movie plays 27 years before my visit. This was great!This movie shows a yound Ethan Hawke and this must have been his breakthrough. The acting is very good also from Julie Delpy.Since I know that there are two sequels I am really looking forward to watch them righ away!

title: Definitely in my top ten...
content: Never before has conversation been this interesting! This movie is so realistic that you almost feel like you're eavesdropping... all the little nuances of a beginning relationship are captured, from the nervous glances in the listening booth to the awkward proposal of the first kiss. Never does this wander into cliches, it sticks to its own pace and captures the magic between this couple. I have never felt so personally involved in a movie- when the sun rose I felt like crying. I was screaming, GET ON THE TRAIN JESSE!!! And yet it ends realistically, without fully satisfying the audience with the "yay everything's perfect" ending. However, it's an appropriate ending, and leaves you wishing for a sequel you know will never come. Filmmaking at its best, Linklater deserves a lot of respect.

title: Chill, low-key romance film.
content: The dialogue and chemistry between the couple was surprisingly intellectual, natural and enjoyable too. However, I felt the ending was more of a tease than something sentimental. If the ending and core message worked for me, I could see myself appreciating this a lot more. But as someone who doesn't resonate with the message of the film and its approach towards relationships, it could only do so much for me. The message just seemed pointless and didn't feel right for them, or in general. Still, it was well-executed for what it was.

title: Realistic portrayal of real romance. But the main couple is not relatable to me, too artsy people
content: The insecurity of first date is realistic, realizing that few awkward comments like "Nice bridge" when walking on an ordinary bridge or nervous first kiss doesn't mean there is no chemistry, very realistic. The fact real life is not perfect, disagreement is not a fight. It's all very realistic, and way better than most romantic Hollywood movies.However, they are completely different people than me. They are a bit too "everything I say needs to be super deep", a bit too bohemian art types. So I couldn't relate, I would probably feel awkward with people like this IRL, not just in the beginning but next morning too.Not all intelligent conversations involve culture, poems or stuff like that. Some couple could both be into math or engineering, and talk passionately about that. Or rock music, sports, whatever. I couldn't relate to them that well.Doesn't make the movie bad, Ethan Hawke's character becomes a writer in the sequel, so it makes sense to be like that. Their conversations were just a bit exhausting at times :D But there was good bits too, although they are thoughts that most thoughful adults have thought of in their life, or something close to it. But still well written, and well delivered.

title: Before Sunrise: Don't see the appeal
content: Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy meet in this critically acclaimed feature presently at time of writing sat at no.214 on IMDb's top 250 movies. They meet, they chat and that's basically the concept of the film.I'm all for "Talkies" but when they have a plot, a purpose, an aim. This seems to lack that and all the core basics a movie must have such as a beginning a middle and an end.Performances are great, the movie is visually appealing but that's as far as it personally goes for me.It's like 90 minutes of having a camera in the Big Brother house and just listening to them waffle on. Only difference is that here the subjects are capable of using words with more than 2 syllable's and aren't desperate Z list celebrity wannabes.Boring, lifeless and I simply don't see the appeal. Out of morbid curiosity I'm sure I'll get round to seeing it's 2 sequels but since I watched Sharknado 2 & 3 that's really not saying much.

title: The best film I've ever seen
content: Wow, I was deeply impressed when I saw that film, the imagination of limiting a relationship to one day sound so incredible to me, but the idea of making that one day the most beautiful one of your life is just wonderful. The topics Jesse and Celine talk about are just those I wonder about, philosophic and really showing the concerns of my generation. Is there a God? Is there love? What is love? What about getting old? I am now planning a trip to Vienna...

title: One Special Night
content: Before Sunrise is a movie so real you can taste it - and you'll want to over and over again. This is a film about two real, intelligent, attractive and sincere people who meet on a European train and agree to spend a night walking around Vienna together. What unfolds is a film so obviously important to both the actors and director, that captures the rare magic of two people falling in love.What makes this film special - aside from the beautiful shots of Vienna, and the superb acting of both Delpy and Hawke - is that it consists of a series of conversations that are interesting without being self-important. Both characters are imperfect, and have a believable mixture of realism and naivety. While the film may sound like a boring chick flick, it is anything but.Director Linklater manages to create a movie that allows viewers to feel like they are right there with Jesse and Celine, falling in love at the same time. By the time the movie ends, you won't be able to wait to rent "Before Sunset", the equally believable, moving sequel that was released nine years later.

title: Wish it would happen for real.
content: This is a wonderfully romantic film.  It is played so realistically that you feel that it could really happen, if only. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy fill the screen with realism, both of love and the script.  What a date flick, and one you would never call a chick flick. I can't believe that love stories like this don't appear that often and we have to put up all the other ones that have relationships that are destined for a happy ending from the outset. Love stories by independent film makers seem to fill that gap created by Hollywood, a filling craved by intelligent audiences.

title: The Difference One Day Makes
content: Before Sunrise is in my opinion one of the greatest movies ever.  There is not a whole lot of action, but what makes the movie powerful are all the great lines.  They met on a train.  How random is that?  It gives every single person a sense of hope.

title: Charming and engaging
content: Directed and co-written by Richard Linklater, this is an unusual work with a minimal amount of plot, a minimum number of characters, and a short period of time but a good deal of dialogue and characterisation. Two strangers in their early 20s meet on a train and, on impulse, decide to spend a night walking round Vienna together. Some viewers will find this slow and inconsequential but I was charmed and engaged.The movie is made by its two young stars: Ethan Hawke as the American Jesse and Julie Delpy as the French Celine. The dialogue and the acting are both so naturalistic that we feel as if we're listening in to a real-life conversation and my favourite scene is when each character in turn pretends to be calling a friend and talks about the person they've just encountered. Jesse and Celine have never met before and will probably never meet again and yet, over the hours, they are powerfully drawn together as we are to them.

title: Simplistic and by design timeless romantic drama
content: Simplistic and by design timeless romantic drama about an American man and a French woman, both in their early 20s, who meet by chance on a train from Budapest to Paris and decide to get off in Vienna to spend one evening and night getting to know each other. Director Richard Linklater may not have a naïve outlook on love and life, but his film is definitely a proponent for purity as his two protagonists wander around Vienna talking about life in general - often with a hint of existentialism - and now and then bump into various odd characters around the town. The film's simplistic form is both its strength and restriction, since it makes so much rely on the quality of the dialogue and acting. And Hawke and Delpy manage to get an earnestness across, complete with real-life insecurities and clumsiness, that elevates Before Sunrise above the run-of-the-mill romantic drama. Still, Linklater's writing has its moments of tackiness, and the film, for all its proposed ingenuity and truthfulness, feels a little too much like Brief Encounter's no. 1 fan to be a really authentic representative for Generation X.

title: Sth sth...
content: It was a surprising movie for me. I was amazed when they talked about the ideas that I've been thinking about them, I was thinking that those ideas only could come from my mind. But i think, we don't have an idea that no one has thought about it. Getting lost in a train travel is one of my dreams ( i know it is cliche). And lastly, the day they spend on is my birthday: 16th of June. There are so much ingredients in this movie that i can relate to me. In conclusion: This movie is a story of my mind an feelings.

title: The Ideal Romantic Movie
content: This was a recommendation from a good friend of mine.He said it was his favorite romantic movie of all time. And I will say I enjoyed the storyline a ton.A quick trip from one man with a large dopamine effect of lustful love between a strangers he meets.It's the fictional European tale of lust that humans have preconceived notions of.

title: A addictive love story
content: Never thought a love story could be so interesting, the conversations so engaging, fun , authentic and believable and not at all cliche.Every bit of mine wanted to have more of Jesse and Cecile.

title: Impossibly romantic
content: Echoing what many others say here, this movie remains an all-time romantic classic. It far surpasses the follow-ups in the Linklater 'trilogy' which I found pretty underwhelming. I guess both actors are younger here (significantly), and while both are annoying in their own way, there's a real spontaneity and authenticity about their flirtation. Hawke is basically dodgy and untrustworthy; Delpy is vain and flighty, yet their conversations are a delight, possibly because they remind us all of our student days when we'd talk late into the evening about life, the universe and everything. And thus the reason so many return to this film every ten years or so is because it makes us feel young again; it probably even brings a tear to our rheumy eyes...

title: Masterpiece.
content: You may think this movie is just another boy and girl cliché but if you think so, you are sorely mistaken. Before Sunrise is one of those movies who you want to be one of the characters. From the beginning, you can already feel a chemistry between the characters and it only increases more and more throughout the film. You can feel the romance developing as they talk to each other in those well-written dialogues. Jesse and Celine aint just another romance movie couple, they are one of the best.10/10.

title: Brilliant, ethereal watch
content: The reason why most guys like me don't enjoy romance films is because oftentimes they degrade into melodramatic, soppy, cringey outbursts of emotion. Before sunrise is the opposite of this. It is founded on a simple plot and premise, of two people who have connected emotionally on a train exploring the city of Vienna. Much of the dialogue involves them walking and talking about everything under the sun(or stars), and it is absolutely enthralling and captivating. The locales in this film are superb, with Vienna and its unique characters offering more than just a pretty backdrop, and actually revealing character traits of Jesse and Celine.(Jesse is cynical, Celine an idealist). Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy also offer superlative performances here, their acting and dialogue delivering a realism that is sorely lacking in most films today.(case in point, the kiss on the Prater Ferris wheel, or them stealing glances at each other at the Vinyl record store) Before Sunrise is not a film that will make you cry, but it is the sort of film that will be stuck in your head weeks after you have seen it.

title: An Extraordinary Day in the Lives of Two Ordinary Strangers.
content: Before Sunrise is a single day adventure in the lives of two strangers who meet on a train in Europe, begin a discussion, instantly connect with one another & slowly end up falling in love, all the while knowing that they have just this one evening to spend together & will be heading to their different directions the next day. From start to finish, there is no definite story or plot present in the film but only conversations about random things or each other and in the end, this chitchat between them turned out to be the only thing that mattered most because it told us everything there is to know about the characters, their views on life & love and even goes on to justify the existence of this story in the first place.Exquisitely directed by Richard Linklater, who came up with this story by taking a leaf out of his own life & refined the screenplay to a great length to give it a completely natural & instinctive appearance. The lush cinematography beautifully captures the dazzling locations of Vienna, the editing is brilliantly carried out and the performances by Ethan Hawke & Julie Delpy as Jesse & Céline respectively is the core ingredient which provides this absolutely devouring dish its very own heart & soul. On an overall scale, Before Sunrise is one of the most intriguing, original & heartwarming romantic dramas I've had the pleasure to watch. Each frame here is as magical as love itself, and that's coming from a guy who isn't even very fond of this genre in the first place. Highly recommended.

title: Troubled simplicity
content: I was apprehensive going into this movie. I think the free flowing nature of this film is perfect. It's the uncertain beginning stages of meeting somebody and having a great connection with them, it's all the small intricacies that some films leave out... the awkward silences, not trying to overstep each others thoughts, the random conversations about anything and everything, the gradual process of getting to know somebody and all that comes with it. And I think this film hits that on the head perfectly. The reason for my review title is because love is never as "simple" as what it seems and perhaps should be at face value, it's usually more complicated and in this case it comes in the form of both Jesse and Celine living worlds apart but making the absolute most out of the time they have because they are both aware of the limited time they might share. Honestly, you should watch this movie, it's incredible.

title: A very simple but very human film, with very good feelings and dialogue.
content: Contrary to what I like to do, I saw this film after seeing its sequel, "Before Sundown". It's a very nice story about an American tourist who is enchanted by a French student he meets on the train on the way to Vienna, and invites her to spend some time with him. The rest of the film is an intense dialogue between the two through the streets of the city, as emotions and feelings develop.The best thing this film has to offer is the surprising and intensely credible interpretation of the main actors. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are both young, elegant and seem to make a nice couple (of course, the characters, not the actors). I don't know if I'm the only person to think this way, but it seems like the actors felt what the characters were feeling, to the extent that there was sympathy or mutual understanding between the two professionals, and a chemistry that permeated entirely to us. .Directed and written with great skill by Richard Linklater, the film can summarize the first meetings of many young couples out there, and I have no doubt that there are many people who will easily identify with the two characters. Who has never chatted with someone cute on a train or bus? There are friendships that start like this, and I myself have a similar case in my life: I have a friend that I value very much, who is blind and who I met by chance on the train, helping her to sit down on more than one occasion (we were both regular travelers due to work). It's a very human film, full of feelings, and full of good dialogues.

title: Amazing - Ethan was good
content: 'Before Sunrise' is not a film to be scrutinised, nor studied. The absolute beauty of it lies in its perfection as a simple love story - of two lives suddenly thrown together in the midst of reality, and the ensuing night of simple love that follows. Every individual at some time in life dreams of the connection that is portrayed in this film between Jesse and Celine, and few ever find it. 'Before Sunrise' simply and elegantly demonstrates how the most fundamental passions of human emotion can envelope two complete strangers. The beauty of this film is that the story is the most important element. The ending is both provocative and emotional - scenes of the night previously seen in darkness are now portrayed in lonely daylight as the sun rises and the story closes on these two characters.I saw this film by accident one night late on television. I have never forgotten it. So well is it made that the audience never question if this could ever really happen in life, reality being so absolutely characterised in it.'Before Sunrise' is simply the story of two strangers bound in Vienna's lonely night splendour - one night of love in all its glory, one superb piece of film making.

title: Vienna we love.
content: It really is a nice plot. These types of things are not that uncommon or common in life. I do not know are these romantic things possible in the real life. I guess they are. Or not? It is up for a debate. But after all it is only a film. Vienna is a great set for a beautiful story like this.Acting is excellent, they act so well, it is almost as they are a real couple somewhere in Vienna.I can see that big question here is did they have sex on their first date? Does it really matter? It is not that important, their relationship will become more complicated as the time passes, in the real life these romantic beginnings end up as a disastrous divorces or break ups even before marriage.

title: Bring a pillow. You'll need it.
content: I'm sure this movie looks good on the resumes of Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy. It's well acted. Basically a 2 person talkfest for 101 minutes. I'm sure the director and actors are very proud of it. Students of acting will appreciate it.But as entertainment for a wider audience, it has little value. It doesn't take long for the viewer to realize these never ending conversations for the sake of making a movie about conversations are all you're going to get. So if at any point you decide to tune out, you won't miss anything. And if you try to make it through to the end, you may have to fight sleep.It doesn't help that, at least in my opinion, Hawke, despite being a fine actor, lacks charm or charisma. He's always very believable in his roles but doesn't make you want to keep watching. It's as though he's always giving a good performance about a not very interesting character. I wouldn't be surprised if the most common response to his name is a shrug and "He's okay."I can't give this film higher than a "2" because I think it has value to acting students but little or no entertainment value to the general public.

title: Worth Your Time
content: I'm a huge movie fanatic. I'm a sucker for a good piece of film. I also adore trilogy's IF executed properly. I'm a 22 year old male. Stereotypically, this type of genre and theme are way out of my realm. I absolutely adored this trilogy, I was heavily invested in every piece of dialogue, every body mannerism, every hidden message, you name it. This was one of the few films (3) that I was solely invested with in terms of genuine conversation. I loved the 90s-style European setting, I loved the old school fashion and I loved the integration of "true love". It really allowed the viewer to take a step back and feel as if they were in their past again. I loved the execution, I loved the general idea behind the three films. I'm over a decade late on the review, however I hope there's many late viewers who use this as a recommendation to indulge in something new.

title: One night as one life
content: Ah, man, here goes another deeply personal movie. I can't say I had specifically met a woman on a train with whom I spent a night walking the streets of an unfimilar city, but the feeling of the inevitable and imminent closure to the chapter I happened to share with this human being is so dear to my heart. If you really think about it, you will understand that closure of that chapter when you say goodbye to someone, to someone who was making you feel special, is like a little death - a death of the exact person that someone was making you feel like, a death of the best version of yourself.The movie made me feel the way movies rarely do. I completely dissolved myself in the story, I ceased to exist, there was no me - I was the main characters which were more alive on the dead surface of my screen than the majority of people I know.It is mind-boggling that something created on the opposite side of the planet, one year before I had a chance to see the light of the world, would be able to resonate with me with that strength 27 years later. That's truly what art is supposed to do: transcend space and time.

title: Romance genre redefined
content:
This movie ruins romance genre forever for me. when i heard the plot of the film, Two strangers talk over a night, i was like "Tell me more".
It is more better if you don't know anything. The movie starts with Jessi and Celine, strangers on the same train, while he asks her out
to visit Vinena together and rest is what follows. They talk about love, live, death but in the most romantic and natural way, I know it
sounds contradictory.
Richard Linklater creates a mood of love, of yearning. Nothing seems reheresed but everything is. That is the best compliment a director can
get. Earlier to this film, I used to laugh at people who said things like they fell in love with a character, i mean this is more suspension of
disbilief than asked for. Both actors personify perfection of each gender.
You would have to wait 9 years for the sequel and 9 years more for the next sequel. I had never smiled throughout a film, there is seemingly no
conflict yet it is the perfect story there can ever be.

title: obsessed
content: I saw this film while i was in a bus and the sun was setting down. It was a mystical experience !!!! That is the aesthetic i want in my life like that guy looking at me with that look in his eyes while i'm listening music idk.

title: very good  in retrospect
content: I started to truly appreciate Before Sunrise after the third installment of this "series", Before Midnight, filmed two decades later. Without this dimension, knowing that there were two more movies with the same characters and in the same vein, Before Sunrise would have been just another art-house movie.We follow the protagonists that meet accidentally on the train. They seem to be the ideal Western combination, French female polyglot and American male with artistic tendencies. They spend a night together in Vienna and discover their own landmarks of the city.What sets apart this movie with from all other similar features is the dialog. The whole movie is more or less one lengthy conversation with all advantages and disadvantages such an approach might bring with itself. Yet, they touch all possible topics interesting to the people of their age, presumably early twenties. They range from abstract thought on life, arts and passage of time to reference of the civil war in the former Yugoslavia, raging couple of hundreds of kilometers away.

title: Beautiful Storyline
content: Inspired by personal experiences, Linklater collaborated with Krizan, who previously appeared in his films Slacker (1991) and Dazed and Confused (1993), to develop the screenplay. Casting was extensive; it took nine months for Hawke and Delpy to be cast with principal photography taking place entirely in Vienna.The plot is considered minimalistic, consisting mostly of monologues and casual conversation with extended dialogue as the characters navigate Vienna. Their contrasting ideas and perspectives on life and love are detailed, with Jesse a romantic disguised as a cynic, and Céline seemingly a romantic. Before Sunrise also explores time, death, and self-discovery.

title: My first romantic movie..yes !
content: It was a great movie with full of honesty and love, caring between two people. This movie is really good !! Plzz have a look on it

title: nothing to spoil
content: Pure, unadulterated spectating hell:  plotless, over-sentimentalized, and one-dimensional, a tour de force of boredom, obviously deeply convinced of its own "insight", so let's throw pretentious in there for good measure.I suspect that those responsible for this film's outsized rating on this site may also be held responsible for Ethan Hawwkee's status as a bestselling "writer".

title: Best romance I've ever seen
content: I absolutely adored this film. There's a good amount of romance movies out there, but I find that most of them seem to lack the realness because they do not contain awkward moments. In the first half of Before Sunrise, we found the characters fumbling over how to act. In one particular scene, the couple was traveling by tram when Jesse tried to put Celine's hair behind her ear but she moved too fast and he imminently had to cancel his act. And also the fact that they meet a couple of amateur actors who invites them to a play. The story is so incredibly real and believable.Dialoge is also interesting and seem very believable. For example, when Jesse brings up a thought he had about reincarnation, where he instantly apologize to Celine if hes being confusing.I would recommend this movie for anyone. It's one of my absolute favorites.

title: Under my Top20's
content: Before Sunrise (1995)A wonderful movie, from the plot to the dialogs to the characters; Its still one of my favorite movies and probably under the Top20Best-Movies-Ever for my kind of taste.Some former comments certainly show a different kind of taste for romances and "lifetalk".Yet I couldn't deny the dept of their philosophical topics especially existentialism.I can warmly recommend the second part: "Before Sunset"kind regards

title: The germination of a fantastic love story
content: Having finally seen the beginning of what turned out to be an extraordinary trilogy after watching it in a peculiar order (Sunset, Midnight, Sunrise), I have to say that it's probably one of the most rewarding cinematic experiences of our lifetime. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy light up the screen as two 20-something strangers who have a chance encounter and from there form a connection which builds over a summer night in Vienna.I was aware of the film when it was in came out, but at the time it was simply not for someone my age or gender, so naturally it passed me by. But having seen all three films now, watching this film in retrospect gives me a greater sense of time and how youth can be so fleeting. It also makes for a nice capsule in depicting the young perspective of Generation X, an age group that seemingly came and went so quickly in terms of being the movers and shakers in society.Seeing this film 25 years after it came out made me very nostalgic about the era it takes place in. That being said, I'm sure this film would have stood firmly as a classic even if it had not been followed by long-term sequels. Recommended to viewers of all ages.

title: Worth revisiting, years later
content: This is a little gem of a movie, and I think that's well established by now. But I'm here to recommend, specifically, that you revisit it (and its sequals) every 5-10 years. I think you'll be surprised how much you've grown and changed, surprised how much your experiences with love and life have continually re-shaped your perspective, surprised at the new levels of meaning you can take from this simple, hopeful, life affirming flick.

title: I don't want to see that sunrise
content:
We'll just make tonight great.Bye
Goodbye
Au revoir
Later.Conversational cinema holds a special part for me. If done right, I could go through more emotions just by listening to people talking than watching any other movie genres.This philosophical yet beautifully romantic movie left me with feelings and yearning. Ethan Hawks and Julie Delpy were a match in heaven. It's weird how drawn in I was, watching a couple walking about Vienna and talking about life, death, reincarnation, morality, feminism, and more. I could listen for twice the movie runtime, and maybe I wouldn't even be bored.That fake telephone scene. Oh my, it's one of those few times that I catch so much feelings. The more they talked, the more I wanted the soon-to-be sunrise to never come.On one hand, I think that it didn't really matter whether I understood what they were discussing about or not, because the chemistry and seemingly genuine interest between the two characters are the real point.However, on the other hand, I think it's important that I comprehend the idea from each conversation. I had this thought that the movie isn't really realistic, because who would ever talked that much philosophy on a honeymoon? But then maybe it's not meant to be realistic. By discussing so many aspects of life yet included them inside one small but significant night, the director wanted me to be able to appreciate the wholeness of life while not forgetting the little moment that also makes life special. And that's exactly what I felt.Also to the point that the movie felt unrealistic and absurdly peaceful. What if, these two characters just recently died. Now they are in some kind of purgatory before going to heaven. That's why they talked about life and death, reflecting on their lives. And also why they can only meet each other for one night before going to heaven. It may not make sense.Overall, it's one of the most beautiful piece of cinema that immersed me from the moment the conversation started. 10/10.

title: Uncommon completeness of an Incomplete Romance lacks the Concrete Vision but still makes a Super Film out of it.
content:
Before Sunrise (1995) :
Brief Review -Uncommon completeness of an Incomplete Romance lacks the Concrete Vision but still makes a Super Film out of it. I read some comments where some people called this Film as 'Casablanca of 90s'. Are your joking? Just go to hell for this comment. Don't you dare try and comparing any just good for sake movie with Legendary Casablanca. Anyways, lets move to Before Sunrise. Yes, it's a Superb Film no doubts. But the fact cannot be denied that it had a chance and potential of becoming a Cult Classic if there was a concrete vision and assertive characterisation. It is a story of 2 strangers who meet on a train and after having a small interesting conversation they decide to spend a night hanging out. They already knew that this is going to last till sunrise but throughout the journey none of them ever stays clear and strict on it. Thier thinking and original plan fluctuates unnecessarily because after having some out of brain ideas they are in mood of typical Romance. Well, it sucks when you begin it atypically and then turns back to typical stuff. Thier conversation and thoughts are very much interesting and innovative but sometimes very immature. The biggest problem with the film is it lacks a concrete theory from the beginning but then it goes even lower because it lacks unpredictability. Dialogues are sensible and engaging, cinematography is fantastic. Some shots are long and have been shot on real locations such as streets, hotels, train etc. Performances by Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are fine. Richard Linklater's direction is very good and nothing much to bash for except some mistakes in the writing. Overall Before Sunrise makes a Super Uncommon Trip which is little common unfortunately but still a Fantastic Watch. A good change from 90s cliche Romance of Hollywood.RATING - 7/10*By - #samthebestest

title: A Minimalistic Masterpiece
content: I am amazed by this movie. That is surprising considering the fact that there is not much that occurs in this movie apart from talking. Before Sunrise is a romantic movie in which two people meet in a train and decide to spend a day together despite the fact that they just met and are unlikely to see each other ever again. The performances from Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy is real and not exaggerated like we see in a lot of movies. The entire film seems like it is taken from our lives and we can totally relate to the characters and the circumstances that they are in. The movie is filled with wonderful ideas about life and the meaning of it. Richard Linklater must be praised for making a movie like this and I would love to see movies that are similar. A good screenplay is the cornerstone of any great movie and Before Sunrise is no exception. An interesting aspect of this movie is that the entire film takes place in a 24-hour time span. This movie must be seen if you like sensible movies and a realistic story.

title: Simple love is the most difficult.
content: This is an extremely touching love film, but it is also an extremely simple love story: a pair of men and women met on the train and had a good impression, spending a night in Vienna together, that's all. There are no ups and downs and no memorable events that sublime the two people's simple feelings; just normal dating, eating, chatting and drinking. This is basically a love story with no plot.But in the middle of this simple plot, two of the most important themes of love are actually explored: the loss of love and the gain of love. The beauty and immortality of this story is first of all in the shortness of this love. But beautiful love must often be short-lived. As the two protagonists in the story said: we are often bored with ourselves, because we cannot escape from ourselves, we must endure ourselves all the time. If two people in love do n't know how to let love flow at the right time, then love will eventually die by itself, because if we ca n't even bear ourselves, how can we endure the other person all the time? What?The death of love (the death of love) and the loss of love (the loss of love) are two different things. When the flame of love is not extinguished, the initiative to lose love is actually to perpetuate love in a certain sense. Just like the 13-year-old girl in the unnamed cemetery: Ten years later, the 13-year-old heroine grew up 10 years old, but the little girl who lost her life is still only 13 years old. The lost life, on the contrary, made her thirteen-year-old become eternal; those who did not lose their life, let youth die slowly. The active distinction on the platform has made this love a classic eternity; before love has died naturally, actively squeezing the burning fire is actually lighting a candle that never extinguishes in the heart.Another reason why this love can be so touching and so beautiful is the perfect and natural beginning of this love. The two naturally talk, naturally feel good, naturally hold hands, naturally kiss, neither resist nor force, like is like, frank is. When you fall in love with those lovely lips, the lips are already on your tongue, because they know your desire for them, and they also desire your caress.Such a simple love start is actually the most difficult to get in real life-not because this love is too complicated to get, but just because it is too simple to get. Love in life often has too many strategic calculations, as the French actress in the movie said: too much thought, too much self-protection. How many boys dare to invite a girl who meets on the train to spend the night with him in an unfamiliar city, and how many girls will confess their love so actively? A kiss is just the beginning of a love, but we are afraid to fail only after we have discovered everything. You do n't know that too many things can never be discovered before love begins.The simplest love is the most rare, but the simplest love is also the most touching. Do n't let love turn into soap operas in Hong Kong and Taiwan; hold hands and hug love on the grass, and say goodbye to the active kiss on the train station platform

title: Talk, talk, more talk, and then some talking
content: I bought this movie as a double feature with its sequel, "Before Sunset", because my sister told me that I'd like them.Not knowing what to expect, I put the disc in... and waited... and waited... and waited, as the actors did a lot of talking.The central characters met by chance on a train, and spent a night together in Vienna before each had to move on to separate destinations. From my perspective, it felt like a thousand and one nights.The character of Celine was what you'd expect a stereotypical young Parisienne to be - stars in her eyes, dreamily romantic, believing in things mystical, while he was the cynical American who shot down everything she found special. So what did she see in him, I ask? They talked about how they 'connected', but they didn't appear, to me, to be connected at all. I didn't see two characters into whom I could become immersed, or believe their developing passion. All I saw were two actors.As a general rule, I wouldn't go out of my way to watch romance movies. That is not to say that I am not capable of being moved by one that is well-cast and well-made. There are many that have stirred my emotions, some even to the point of tears ("An Affair to Remember", for example, which this kind of takes a page from). But not this one. The Kleenex was left undisturbed in its little box, this time.Maybe the other users who've given this movie its high rating are hopeless romantics who'd cry over a sentimental TV commercial. I don't know. I don't mean to demean them in any way, but maybe some people have a lower 'romance' threshold than others...I simply could not get involved with the characters. They didn't do anything for me but leave me cold.The reason I gave this a 4 out of 10 instead of a 3, is for the Viennese scenery.Watch this if there's nothing else on, and if you're doing something else at the same time so that you're not too bored.

title: opposites attract
content: Jesse and Ceiline are brought together on a train when an old married couple have a very public fight in that way that only old married couples can manage. Two things become clear very quickly to the young couple - they have chemistry, and the time they can spend together is extremely limited. They set about making the most of mystical. magical, slightly unreal experience. They meander through Vienna, occasionally encountering some minor colourful characters, who despite being finely drawn, are always just a sideshow to the intense, fragile, painfully exposed musings of the young couple.Hawke and Delpy do a superb job of making an implausible situation seem all too natural and engrossing. Their dialogue could all too easily be self-absorbed and twee (My Blueberry Nights?), but here it is apt and at times incisive. "I fee like I am taking notes, waiting for my real life to begin," says Jese. Much of the success of the film is down to how the observations of the two characters resonate so closely with our own existential concerns.I made the mistake of watching Before Sunset before watching this. I wish I had encountered them chronologically. Both films are recommended, but only for those who like a slower pace, wry observation, and sheer, unadulterated romance.

title: Very Thought-Provoking!
content: Before Sunrise, the first film in the trilogy by Richard Linklater, is a very powerful, thought-provoking film that I never thought would be good. This film has no action and is merely conversation, so how can this movie be so good? Well, this movie is about as close to reality as you can get. What happens in this movie could happen to anybody out there. Secondly, the script is tight and well-written. I really loved all these meaningful, philosophical conversations. I'm usually bored at mostly talk films, but the way I was grabbed into these conversations really means the movie worked.Linklater's film is about a French girl on her way back to school and an American guy heading to Vienna to take a flight home and how they started a connection with each other when they met on the train.The acting is about as good as you can get. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy have great chemistry and the way they delivered the dialog is just special. There is no need for supporting characters because the focus is on these two characters and their meanings of life.Overall, this is a very special, powerful film. I honestly didn't want to see this movie since I thought it would be a stupid romantic comedy, but it is really not. It's a drama that's thoughtful, funny, poignant, and just very sweet. I honestly don't get this "R" rating because the dialog would be very meaningful for teens. For those who love cinema, this is a great movie to watch. I rate this film 9/10.

title: AMAZING
content: I am a huge fan of Linklater's films, and this is probably my favorite one of them. Great acting, and I absolutely love this type of writing.

title: The first of three "Before..." movies
content:
(1995) Before Sunrise
DRAMA/ ROMANTICPeople who're older and are patient may be able to enjoy this film than younger people, since all it shows are two people just basically talking throughout on certain issues and on specific subjects in a civilized manner and we get to hear their opinions on it. And they eventually get romantic during the process while walking through the streets of Vienna. Co-written and directed by Ricahrd Linklater, that is almost improvising, and while the Julie Delpy character seemed real, the Ethan Hawke character doesn't seem real enough, who some times tends to direct conversation away from himself, and that at times is not interesting at all. The first of eight movies Ethan Hawke collaborated with writer/ director Richard Linklater.

title: The Legend
content: One of the best romance movies ever in my life. I really really fall in love with their inspirational, clever, and logical (in a heartful way) conversation. Def gave me some space to think about what matters in life and the world.

title: Beautiful & Poetic....
content: 7.5/10I've had this film on my watchlist for quite some time and wasn't too sure when, or if, I'd ever get around to it, but I'm glad I finally did. Although it didn't reach the level of expectations I had set out. It was still a beautifully poetic film.The chemistry isn't in your face between Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy, but they definitely make it work. Their awkwardness bounces of each other perfectly, as they don't know each other of the bat, and it's not a snap of the fingers that their relationship reaches its pinnacle point. No, they have to reach it through the natural progression of the story that way it becomes "true love", and for me that was beautiful.If I was in a relationship. I could see this film being a date night movie maybe eight months or more into that relationship. The reason being is that the film takes place in one night, but a lot happens. So much so that it recalls the experience in such a way that you may sit there thinking with your significant other about how you became to be in a relationship, or the fun times you've had throughout it. So though this film sort of feels like a documentary of two peoples lives through one night. It still very personable.The last thing that impressed me about the film is that it is supposed to take place in Vienna. And that's exactly where it's filmed. So it gives a real environment to work with giving more life to the story.Overall, I truly enjoyed the film. I definitely think it's worth checking out more so if you're a couple. It's a beautiful representation of love that doesn't feel watered down, forced, or cheesy.Thank you for reading my review. I hope it helps you understand the film, and make a future decision on it. Until next time.... Enjoy the show!

title: A simply brilliant snapshot of life at that age at that time
content: It's rare that I give a film 10 out of 10. I am one to regularly give films harsh reviews (even supposedly good ones).This was simply captivating cinema and I'm strangely annoyed that I hadn't seen it sooner.It's not about the story. It's about the people in it. The acting is brilliantly natural and I couldn't help by look back at my times of my early 20s, where your eyes are opening to the realities of life and the world, holding onto optimism, coming to grips with the concept of love, dealing with disappointment and resentment, social awkwardness; and contemplating ones own mortality.These things form the basis of many conversations throughout the film as two travelers almost "suspend reality" while they fall in love over night, then grapple with it all ending at sunrise. There is this magnificent line when Ethan Hawke said "we're back in real time" which evokes strong memories of magical European nights that you never wanted to end and time feels like it stops.It moved me deeply, but not in a depressing way. It simply stirred a lot of reflection on the past and the way we all were once upon a time. For those who have traveled to Europe and had many random nights, this provides so many snapshots that you will be able to related to.Best of all, it didn't fall into mushiness and become a sloppy Hollywood love film with a happy ending. It was a deep, but totally realistic, well made film, with great scenic contrast and mesmerizing direction. I can't recommend this enough and look forward to the sequels.

title: Unique but still fantastical
content: I thought this film was pretty unique - it has zero budget and is just walking around and talking. Yet still quite captivating as there is a growing emotional connection. It didn't seem genuine to me though. James was way too forward and I kept thinking "how can he really get away with saying that?" so the interactions sometimes appeared absurd and ironically it seemed like a "male fantasy".

title: I barely survived.
content: This is singularly the worst movie I have ever seen. With a complete lack in plot, the only redeeming facet is a shining moment of honesty on the train in which they blatantly tell you that this will be a horrible film. I managed to survive the full length on only the dire hope that SOMETHING would eventually happen. I was disappointed. If you are considering renting, I suggest you go for ice cream instead.

title: Don't miss it and allow yourself to be a version of Jesse or Celine for 90plus minutes
content: My best friend had his student apartment in Spittelberg - in Viennas 7th district - in 1993, when he called me once, and told me, that they are shooting a film right in front of his door. We both couldn't care less. About a year later we went to the movies on a Wednesday, where surprise sneak previews were screened, not knowing what to expect of this particular movie night.The screening was Before sunrise. I movie that I loved right away and that still captivates me, every couple of years I see it.It's simple, it's full of cliches (I've never seen a palm reader nor a street poet in Vienna ever!), it's some random talks between 2 young adults who want to impress their counterparts with their (pseudo)intellectuality, and still it portrays life the way it often is. We all had those evenings and nights, were we felt super clever, were we fell for someone or just for the thought of it. And that's what Before Sunrise is. It's tale about us. It's a blueprint of 20somethings in the 90s. It's about falling in love or truely believing it's love. It's about the morning after, were the night before becomes a faded memory.Richard Linklater, the fantastic Ethan Hawke and July Delpy made it possible to create a movie, that mirrors our lifes, that allows us to see us through someone elses eyes. Films rarely do that and that's what makes Before sunrise a little treasure of filmmaking. Ethan Hawke once said in an interview about his movie "First Reformed" that a good movie starts after you have watched it (or something like that...). That's true with Before sunrise, because when the end credits have rolled, it makes you feel something. Almost 30 years ago it was the pain of lost love and the sadness of a great night passed for me. And it still does after watching it at the age of 50.Thanks for the movie and their great sequels.Btw, my friends entrance door was in the small alley, were Jesse and Celine sat down on some pallets, if anyone wonders.

title: Beautiful movie
content: I enjoyed this movie watching it for the first time in 2021 it still felt relatable. The cinematography was wonderful. For a story being about two people walking around Vienna it never got boring I felt the dialogue and acting in sequence with the events and places they were going to kept you in the movie it is quite wonderful. Would recommend to those that want an interesting romance story.

title: The perfect romance
content: This movie immediately felt special from the very first minutes. Everything about it felt romantic- the meeting on the train, the beautiful European cityscape, the casual, almost disheveled look of the characters- everything felt genuine and natural. I loved how the love blossomed between the characters and how apparent their chemistry was, I loved seeing them make a deep connection and get to know each other before even sharing a kiss. I found myself waiting for them to kiss, wishing for it, because their love felt so pure and palpable. And the ending was absolutely heart wrenching, and the not knowing what happened next (until I watched Before Sunset), even more so. This movie immediately became a favorite.

title: The most beautiful romance I've seen
content: I pulled out this DVD the other day from our library with mixed feelings mainly cos it was a 1995 movie. Guess what? It became the most frank, blunt, yet the most romantic movie I've ever come across. The romantic spark brewing between Jesse and Celine is so natural, you might feel that it is you who are in it! It is so brutally honest!! I loved every bit of it, from the start to the very end, frozen to my couch. It is so intense and engaging. Linklater takes us continuously through a 105 minute journey with those two awesome characters without a flicker of boredom or monotony. He uses very trivial dialogues that are quite common to intelligent conversations of post-modernist societies, but installs a sweet romanticism within each scene. I am really at a loss to understand as to why he was not given the best Director award in that year. The movie commands an absolute smooth rhythm, flows effortless and renders serenity at its best. One of the best movie gems created in our time!

title: great!
content: this is a beautiful film...about two strangers meeting on a train..sort of like serendipity...both intending to go different directions, but by sudden impulse. decide to spend one day and night in vienna together... julie delpy and ethan hawke are incredible in the lead roles..both emotionally connecting with the characters...everyone should go and see it!... unforgettable..

title: Great film
content: Great film. There are tons of beautiful, memorable scenes which I would love to mention. The morning scene after the protagonists made out, the calm tone the director used, I don't no what magic he used, I could feel the exact morning freshness. The scene when they listened to Kath bloom's 'come here' inside a listening booth, that scene was one of my all time favorite movie scenes. Apart from that, there was train conversation, bus conversation, some random people's appearance and some other memorable scenes which will stay in my heart forever. I refer this film as a pure cinematic beauty. Great to see this movie finally made it to the top 250 list of IMDb.

title: Refreshing and beautiful
content: I loved every bit of it.Both characters are very three dimensional and authentic. They share lots of interesting thoughts throughout the film as they get to know and fall for each other.It's very simple and warm aesthetically and feels like a classic. Lots of great quotes.Having watched the full trilogy, however, I sort of wish this was the only film on this story.

title: Not realistic but then again it's a movie
content: Somewhat long winded and the "romance" between Jesse and Celine just seemed forced but they do have chemistry. For me it makes me happy thinking I too could find someone like Celine. She just seems like a wonderful woman I'd love to spend time with being romantic and acting whimsical

title: It's important with whom we see a movie
content: Well, i rated 7/10 this movie, i can't say it is the best i have ever saw, but it's very interesting and there are many amazing scenes.The story is really good and unusual, which makes me write this review. The places are amazing and the small details in the movie, really created a very romantic story.The fact is that this one is the first movie i saw with her, and that can only make me love this movie. I will never forget then.I strongly recommend everyone to watch this movie with his / her lover.This is only the first movie of a trilogy which i will watch in the upcoming Fridays.Cheers

title: I fell asleep
content: I waited 27 years to watch this, as I expected it to be corny. I only watched it based on such high reviews. Now I have no trust at all for reviews and audience scores.Boring.I do not agree that there was chemistry. It is all dialogue. The only bits of realness are the coy glances by Ethan Hawke.I really did try to like this but I fell asleep.Not much more to say. Wish I stuck to my intuition that I would not like it!

title: Happy June 16! <3
content: -On June 16, 1994, two strangers met on a train, decided to spend the day together, and fell in love..."I'm a strong, independent woman in my professional life. I don't need a man to feed me but I still need a man to love me and that I could love."

title: Real as it can be
content: Before Sunrise is an experience unlike most movies I've seen. At first, I wasn't sure how to feel about its slower pacing-it took me a moment to adjust. But as the story unfolded, I realized this wasn't just a movie; it was a deeply naturalistic masterpiece. The pacing, the conversations, the silences, it all felt so authentic.The dialogue is where this film truly shines. Jesse and Céline's interactions are brimming with awkward tension and raw, unpolished charm, like two real strangers trying to navigate an immediate attraction. The pauses, the overlapping chatter, the awkward jokes they're so beautifully real and human. It's rare to see a movie capture the spontaneity and imperfections of real conversations this well. At times, I forgot I was watching fiction cause it felt like peering into the lives of two actual people sharing a fleeting moment in time.Cinematically, it might not have extravagant visuals, but that simplicity works perfectly here. The lack of distraction allows the focus to remain on Jesse and Céline's dynamic, making their evolving connection feel even more profound. The depth of their discussions about life, love, dreams, and the passage of time is captivating and thought-provoking. It's incredible how the film uses just two characters and a simple story to explore such relatable themes.I loved it, and I'm excited to see the sequel. There's always a bit of hesitation... how do you follow something so perfectly understated without disrupting its magic? But I'm hopeful.Before Sunrise is a film that proves you don't need elaborate plots or flashy cinematography to create something truly meaningful.

title: a nostalgic and beautiful love movie
content: The movie gave me a lot of pleasure. The characters and their relationships with each other, I think, were very pleasant. Ethan Hawke is an actor I really like, and I think his acting in this movie was also beautiful. The same goes for Julie Delpy, of course. My favorite part of the movie is that it doesn't process the toxic and contrived loves in today's movies. Personally, I didn't characterize that kind of thing as love. It made me really happy to watch Jesse and Celine getting to know each other and being attracted to each other as the hours went by. And I think that's how true love should be, too. If you like romantic movies, you will probably like to watch this movie. I suggest .

title: The Beauty of Conversation
content: This film is breathtaking. In the midst of all the remakes and shallow money-grabs, Before Sunrise is the perfect movie to watch and just marvel at how simple yet wonderful it is. Linklater's attentive direction combined with the heartfelt performances make this the type of film that you can't seem to look away from.Before Sunrise's screenplay delivers on every level -- it's authentic without being pretentious, and every bit of dialogue feels like it came from an honest place. The film is almost entirely conversation, yet it never lags or loses any of its spark because the script allows for Jesse and Céline to feel like real people. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy as the two budding lovers at the film's center are absolutely brilliant. These two work so well together. Not only do they bring the writing to life, but they're also just so beautiful and charming to watch on screen that you can't help but fall in love along with them.Beyond the technical aspects, this movie is really special because it makes you rethink how you talk and converse with others. These two characters know that their time together is limited and that their future is not promised, thus all of their conversations are rooted with that in mind. Despite being total strangers in the beginning, Jesse and Céline enable themselves to be completely open and vulnerable throughout their one day together in Vienna because they know that they may never see each other again. As a viewer, you start to wonder how many meaningful conversations you could be having in your own life if you spoke to others like it was the last time you'd ever see them. For those of us who have built much stronger walls around what we consider deeply personal, Before Sunrise asks the question: what if you tore those walls down? Even more so, what if you invited someone you barely knew inside? Sure, it's intimidating and seemingly impossible to imagine, but that potential to form a genuine connection with another individual is irreplaceable, and Before Sunrise explores it beautifully.This movie is one of the most truthful portrayals of love that I've ever seen. It captures the boundless nature of all human relationships with such care and appreciation. Both sequels are excellent as well, but I have a soft spot for this one specifically. I can only fathom how amazing it would've been to see all three films in real time, each within the nine-year increments (I sadly was not alive when this film first released, and was far too young for the other two). But alas, I'm grateful to have finally seen them now. I'd recommend watching Before Sunrise if you haven't already -- it is well worth your time.

title: I love it
content: I could not decide which one I love more; Before Sunrise or Before Sunset. I think I do not have to.The actors are so real, so human. This film is a masterpiece from my point of view.I would be nice to see this film in my younger age cause it caries so much life info.Thank god that there are humans out there that make this kind of films. You see there is no manual for how to be a human. The picture that we got from our society is a strange one. And this film has changed my own picture.

title: A Long Conversation
content: This was nearly 101 minutes of a young man and woman, having a continuous conversation, through one day and night, after meeting as strangers on a train to Vienna, having both recently rebounded from a prior relationship.I do not remember ever having listened to a continuing conversation through an entire film. The conversation seemed to be an intellectualization of the emotive feeling of love. I surmise there was much wisdom to be discovered, most of which I missed as one might during a long lecture.There was awkwardness then gradually ensuing relaxation. There clearly was ongoing sexual tension. There came occasional annoyance, not turning to anger, as this was newness. Interesting, was the contrasting anger of an argument between an older married couple accompanying them on the train.Though both craved a permanent continuation of their relationship, they fought off the impulse, and held to a promise they would part in 24 hours, as they each had planned before they met. This was wise because most likely in 6-12 months the warm, addicting, experience of sudden love, would have sadly passed and reality brutally replaced it.

title: Wonderful
content: "Before Sunrise" is a great example of a film that engages you with nothing but great writing and acting. There is no plot. Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy meet on a European train and walk around Vienna. They talk. They go to old cathedrals. They talk some more. They go to cafes and bars and restaurants and talk and talk and talk. Boring, right? Nope, not at all.Richard Linklater's first film in the "Before" trilogy is as radical in its own way as Louis Malle's "My Dinner With Andre" in that it has no "story" and uses almost nonstop dialogue to entertain and enlighten. The characters in "Before Sunrise" are eloquent. They are articulate. They feel like real people. "Before Sunrise" is a film of beautiful moments, and it is a refreshing antidote to both the mindless Hollywood garbage and the cynical modern indie hipster trash that passes for art cinema these days.

title: Heartwarming Story!
content: Before Sunrise is a film that captures the essence of love in its purest and simplest form. It tells the story of Jesse and Celine, two strangers who meet on a train and decide to spend one night together in Vienna, exploring the city and each other. The film is not about plot twists or dramatic conflicts, but about the conversations and connections that make us human. The film is realistic, natural, and charming, thanks to the brilliant performances of Hawke and Delpy, who improvise most of their dialogues and create a believable chemistry. The film is also beautifully shot, showcasing the scenic beauty of Vienna and its culture. The film is a rare gem that makes us feel the joy and pain of falling in love, and leaves us with a bittersweet ending that makes us wonder what will happen next.Before Sunrise is one of my favorite films, and I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates romance, realism, and art. It is a film that will make you think, feel, and smile. It is a film that will stay with you long after it ends. It is a film that deserves a 10/10 rating.

title: Give me my one hour and half back please!!
content: I usually don't do this but this time i couldn't help, it. Sorry for all you lovers of this movie, but i've seen love stories, and this is not it! This is a boring two way conversation about things that nobody cares except the writer and intellectual people. I was curious to know why the great rating and all, watched it, still didn't get it. Also, bad acting, bad sound and a few good shots of Vienna, that's it! Ah, and a good thing, it has a lot of EXTREME BOREDOM, i can see more happiness and joy looking to a blank wall during hour and half. To bad my one star rating don't mean anything to the high rating that this movie has. I am curious though to see the the rest of the trilogy (NOT)

title: Heady and Romantic, Hawke and Delpy's Twelve-Hour Fling is a Perfect Encapsulation of the Twenty-Something Ethos
content: A pair of young adults meet on a trans-European railway ride and impulsively agree to spend an evening in Venice, sightseeing their way through the town's coziest locales while getting to know each other. There's little to Before Sunrise's plot structure, just a lazy wander through a foreign metro with loose promises of a flight in the morning, but that's largely the point. These two had nowhere else to be, so they could afford to burn the evening on a whim. Their self-discovery as individuals, and as an unlikely would-be couple, is the real story. This day-long snapshot represents a moment of transition for the both of them, a chance to experience what it means to be a twenty-something in love with the proverbial open road before them. They're old enough to make pragmatic adult decisions, but still naïve enough to see the world through childish eyes. As Céline surmises in one penetrating confession, her overnight travel partner may bare his heart like an old poet, but he still kisses like an adolescent.Jesse and Céline's relaxed, directionless amble makes for refreshing, enchanting cinema; an example of going with the flow and taking life as it comes. The couple is clearly in deep with one another, or maybe with the allure of tasting an exotic fruit, and their mutual sense of inquisitive attraction is radiant. Although they operate on a fixed timer, there's no rush to the shared adventure. This night might just last forever.As far as romantic nostalgia goes, Before Sunrise is right on the mark. Costars Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are a natural fit, starry-eyed enough to embrace the existential philosophies they plumb. To openly ponder life, love, self and spirituality, in an unfamiliar land, with someone they've only known for a few hours. The world is their oyster, and I'm envious, because I can remember being in a very similar head space at their age and was never able to consummate it in a moment half as perfect as this one. Nor, I'd imagine did a vast majority of other viewers. That's one beauty of cinema; risk-free idealization. And, as in life, we don't completely appreciate the magic of such moments until they've passed. This truth is made evident at the film's conclusion, when we quietly revisit the sites of many key scenes, now empty and bathed in morning light, and still feel the couple's presence. What a perfect sendoff.

title: wonderful movie
content: it is probably the best romantic movie i have ever saw,it is the story between the two passengers traveling in the train-talking the most common things happened in there life,both of them wanted to spend the night in Vienna they en-counted with SO many people,culture,language issues,kisses,one night stand so as the part of dating.the romantic scene between them in the park was the best part of the movie.this movie made me crazy about Julie delpy ....man! she is damn beautiful through out the movie.i just wish i could kiss her like ethen hawke kisses her in the morning before they go apart.all the characters looks like real all the credit goes to the director.well every one should watch this movie and there is also sequels for this movie "before sunset" and "before midnight".these movies were released after a long time of the main release.damn how could it doesn't came to my notice of these releases i should probably go and watch now.all i want to tell you all guys just go and watch it, AM sure u don't want to miss this..

title: A movie about nothing... and it was wonderful
content: Lots of nice reviews from readers and critics alike... so I finally got around to checking this out. I was not disappointed. No spin, no contrived plot, no violence, no politics, nothing but genuine feelings, and human frailties. Two strangers meet, connect, throw caution to the wind, and spend the night together walking and talking in a beautiful setting. What could be more pure?I understand the appeal... and here it is: by the time the film rolls into Act III, all the women watching want to be Celine and all the men watching want to be Jesse. It's escapism in its most raw form. For 12-14 hours, I'll leave all my cares behind and get lovingly wrapped up in a beautiful stranger... with no agenda and little hope or concern for the future and what it may bring. It was lovely... and it makes everyone watching fantasize about a time in their lives when they would've wanted nothing more than to do this. There should be more films like this.

title: simple plot yet serving deep spontaneous philosophical conversations
content: The film follows Jesse (Ethan Hawke), an American man, and Céline (Julie Delpy), a French woman, who meet on a train traveling through Europe. On a whim, they decide to spend a night walking and talking through Vienna before Jesse's flight the next morning.This movie has a simple plot but has deep, spontaneous philosophical conversations about life and love between two strangers who meet on a train. It beautifully portrays the beauty of living in the moment.With its naturalistic dialogue, genuine chemistry between the leads, and beautifully captured Vienna backdrops, Before Sunrise is a touching exploration of human connection and the power of a single night to transform lives. It's a poignant reminder of the significance of fleeting moments in our lives.

title: Must watch
content: What an incredible movie.True masterclass, amazing acting,story and specially chemistry between them.Can watch again and again

title: Dreadful dialog
content: This film is 90% dialog. And the dialog is not at all convincing in the given situation. It is too contrived, too pseudo cleverly intellectual, it is irritating and not at all romantic. Whenever Linklater switches to body language (the looks between the couple in the music booth) and purely visual shots (the morning scenes without actors) one begins to feel the deeper emotions that would be present in the given situation. But these moments are way too few and they are drowned in the veritable deluge of "adolescent" conversation between the two main characters. Now I will go and see the next episode "Before Sunset", to see if the director himself has picked up on this grave shortcoming of "Before Sunset". If he has, part 2 might well be a really nice film....!

title: The most fun you're gonna have as a third wheel
content:
Durin this whole movie I felt I was honestly not supposed to be there. I was intruding. But even so I had so much fun. I felt all of their emotions so strongly, even laughed with them out loud.
This movie was the most fun I ever had as a third wheel period.

title: The impact and idea of time and the power of human connection explored in one beautiful package
content: The kind of connection the two lead characters in Before Sunrise merit is the kind of connection I've only managed to achieve a few times in my life; it's the connection with someone who is a complete stranger, but as soon as you meet him, your wall of protection and tact almost completely crumbles. You feel compelled to share personal information with this stranger, deep thoughts that no one other than you have pondered or heard, and talk until your throat is raw about everything you can think of in that given moment. Your become verbally diuretic, and after it's over, you're upset that the conversation has ended, but you've achieved a state of personal tranquility thanks to a release of all that was on your mind that you are at a sort of bliss.
